facts.text: Krishnappa and his two sons-Thimmayya and Venkatanarsu-constituted a Hindu undivided family.

facts.text: On June 25, 1958, the Income-tax Officer made an order under s. 46(5) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 calling upon the Managing Director to withhold the amount of tax due from the salaries payable to Thimmayya and Venkatanarsu.

facts.text: Thimmayya and Venkatanarsu lodged petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Andhra Pradesh at Hyderabad, praying that writs of certiorari or other appropriate writs be issued quashing the order dated June 25, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Thimmayya and Venkatanarsu then lodged petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Andhra Pradesh at Hyderabad, praying that writs of certiorari or other appropriate writs be issued quashing the order dated June 25, 1958 of the Income-tax Officer under s. 46 5 .

facts.text: The petitions were decided by Seshachelapati J. in favour of the two petitioners, and the decision was confirmed in appeal by a Division Bench of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh.

facts.text: The Income-tax authorities have not proceeded against the property of the Hindu undivided family.

issues.text: Whether, after the Income-tax Officer recorded an order under s. 25-A(1) that the family had disrupted with effect from November 2, 1946, steps taken for recovery of the amount of tax assessed without an appropriate order under s. 25-A(2) were invalid?

issues.text: Whether an order of assessment which has become final is liable to be re-opened under s. 25-A(2) by the Income-tax Officer, when an order under s. 25-A(1) is passed by him subsequent to the order of assessment?

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was, in our judgment, in error in holding that an order of assessment which has become final is liable to be re-opened under s. 25-A 2  by the Income-tax Officer, when an order under s. 25-A  1  is passed by him subsequent to the order of assessment.

issues.text: Whether the proviso to sub-section (2) of s. 25-A imposes joint and several personal liability on the members of the HUF for the tax even without an order under sub-section (1)?

anchor.surface_text: The Solicitor-General companytended that the second paragraph of sub-s.  2  which is in the form of a proviso, is in substance a substantive provision imposing joint and several liability for tax assessed on the total income received by or on behalf of the joint family against all members of the family.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the order on the claim made under s. 25-A 1  on June 30, 1952 was given a clear retrospective operation, and the Income-tax Officer was bound to give effect to that order recognising the partition and to follow up the consequences which flowed from the order.

(2) which is in the form of a proviso, is in substance a substantive provision imposing joint and several liability for tax assessed on the total income received by or on behalf of the joint family against all members of the family.

arguments.court_reasoning: Proviso operates only after s.25A(1) order; scheme requires s.25A(1) precondition

arguments.claim: HUF deemed to continue undivided unless order recording partition under s.25A(1)

anchor.surface_text: The Section makes two substantive provisions- i  that a Hindu undivided family which has been assessed to tax shall be deemed for the purposes of the Act, to continue to be treated as undivided and therefore liable to be taxed in that status unless an order is passed in respect of that family recording partition

arguments.claim: Partition claim must be made at time of assessment under s.23 for s.25A(1) inquiry

anchor.surface_text: ii  if at the time of making an assessment it is claimed by or on behalf of the members of the family that the property of the joint family has been partitioned among the members or groups of members in definite portions, i.e. a complete partition of the entire estate is made,

arguments.claim: ITO must assess total HUF income as undivided then apportion under s.25A(2) after s.25A(1) order

anchor.surface_text: Where an order has been passed, the Income-tax Officer must still make an assessment of the total income received by or on behalf of the undivided family as if no partition had taken place, and shall thereafter apportion the income-tax assessed on the total income

arguments.claim: Proviso to s.25A(2) transforms HUF asset liability to personal joint/several liability of members only after s.25A(1) order

anchor.surface_text: The proviso to sub-s. (2) makes a departure of a vital character. Whereas in the case of an assessment of the income of the joint family, the tax liability is charged upon the assets of the family, when upon a partition an order under sub-s. (1) has been recorded all members

arguments.claim: s.25A(2) effective only after s.25A(1) order; no assessment/apportionment otherwise

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section (2) of s. 25-A becomes effective only if an order under S. 25-A(1) is made and not otherwise. In terms the sub-section enacts that the Income-tax Officer shall assess the total income received by or on behalf of the joint family

arguments.claim: Failure to dispose partition claim does not affect ITO jurisdiction to assess HUF as undivided

anchor.surface_text: Failure to make an order on the claim made does not affect the jurisdiction of the Income-tax Officer to make an assessment of the Hindu family which had hitherto been assessed as undivided. The Income-tax Officer may assess the income of the Hindu family

arguments.claim: Final assessments cannot be challenged collaterally or reopened based on later s.25A(1) order

anchor.surface_text: Any error or irregularity in the assessment may be rectified in the manner provided by the statute alone, and the assessment is not liable to be challenged collaterally. In the present case claim was undoubtedly made at the time of making an assessment,

arguments.claim: No machinery to reopen final HUF assessments using subsequent s.25A(1) order

anchor.surface_text: But the Act contains no machinery authorising an Income-tax Officer to re-open an assessment of a Hindu undivided family, relying upon an order made by him under s. 25-A(1) after the order of assessment is made.

arguments.claim: Absent s.25A(1) order at assessment time, tax liability enforceable only against HUF property, not personally

anchor.surface_text: Order recording the partition subsequent to the date on which the order of assessment was made must for reasons aforementioned be ignored and tax levied as if no such order was made. The effect of that step however is that in the absence of an order under s. 25-A(1)

arguments.claim: s.46(5) withholding from salaries invalid as no personal liability arose

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer has sought by resorting to s. 46(5) to attach the remuneration earned by Thimmayya and Venkatanarsu as employees of Krishnappa Asbestos Barytes Private Ltd. this he was incompetent to do.

holdings.text: A Hindu undivided family hitherto assessed as undivided shall be deemed to continue undivided unless an order recording partition under s.25A(1) is passed.

anchor.surface_text: The Section makes two substantive provisions- i  that a Hindu undivided family which has been assessed to tax shall be deemed for the purposes of the Act, to continue to be treated as unadivided and therefore liable to be taxed in that status unless an order is passed in respect of that family recording partition

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.25A last sentence deeming HUF undivided absent order; scheme requires continuity for assessment.

holdings.text: Partition claim must be made at the time of assessment under s.23 for ITO to inquire and record under s.25A(1).

anchor.surface_text: ii  if at the time of making an assessment it is claimed by or on behalf of the members of the family that the property of the joint family has been partitioned among the members or groups of members in definite portions, i.e. a complete partition of the entire estate is made,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory language 'at the time of making an assessment under section 23' mandates timing for claim and inquiry.

holdings.text: Even after s.25A(1) order, ITO must assess total HUF income as if undivided, then apportion tax under s.25A(2).

anchor.surface_text: Where an order has been passed, the Income-tax Officer must still make an assessment of the total income received by or on behalf of the undivided family as if no partition had taken place, and shall thereafter apportion the income-tax assessed on the total income

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit scheme of s.25A(2): assess as undivided despite partition order, then apportion per shares.

holdings.text: Proviso to s.25A(2) transforms HUF asset-based tax liability into personal joint and several liability of members only upon recording s.25A(1) order.

anchor.surface_text: The proviso to sub-s. (2) makes a departure of a vital character. Whereas in the case of an assessment of the income of the joint family, the tax liability is charged upon the assets of the family, when upon a partition an order under sub-s. (1) has been recorded

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso operates post s.25A(1); pre-order liability limited to family assets, post-order personal.

holdings.text: s.25A(2) becomes effective only after an order under s.25A(1) is made.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section (2) of s. 25-A becomes effective only if an order under S. 25-A(1) is made and not otherwise. In terms the sub-section enacts that the Income-tax Officer shall assess the total income received by or on behalf of the joint family

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sub-s.(2) conditioned on 'where such an order has been passed'; no apportionment without precondition.

holdings.text: Failure to dispose of partition claim does not invalidate ITO's jurisdiction to assess HUF as undivided.

anchor.surface_text: Failure to make an order on the claim made does not affect the jurisdiction of the Income-tax Officer to make an assessment of the Hindu family which had hitherto been assessed as undivided. The Income-tax Officer may assess the income of the Hindu family

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory assessment procedure intact; error rectifiable only via statutory appeals, not collateral.

holdings.text: Final assessments cannot be reopened under s.25A(2) based on subsequent s.25A(1) order; no statutory machinery for reopening.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was, in our judgment, in error in holding that an order of assessment which has become final is liable to be re-opened under s. 25-A 2  by the Income-tax Officer, when an order under s. 25-A  1  is passed by him subsequent to the order

holdings.reasoning_summary: No provision to reopen final orders post-appellate confirmation; claim not raised in appeals.

holdings.text: Absent s.25A(1) order at assessment time, HUF tax liability enforceable only against family property, not personally against members.

anchor.surface_text: Order recording the partition subsequent to the date on which the order of assessment was made must for reasons aforementioned be ignored and tax levied as if no such order was made. The effect of that step however is that in the absence of an order under s. 25-A(1)

holdings.reasoning_summary: Liability restricted to family estate pre-s.25A(1); personal liability arises only post-order and apportionment.

holdings.text: s.46(5) order to withhold salaries invalid absent personal liability of members for HUF tax.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer has sought by resorting to s. 46(5) to attach the remuneration earned by Thimmayya and Venkatanarsu as employees of Krishnappa Asbestos Barytes Private Ltd. this he was incompetent to do.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.46(5) targets defaulters' personal assets; no personal liability without s.25A(1) order.

holdings.text: Proviso to s.25A(2) does not impose joint/several liability without s.25A(1) order.

anchor.surface_text: The Solicitor-General contended that the second paragraph of sub-s. (2) which is in the form of a proviso, is in substance a substantive provision imposing joint and several liability for tax assessed on the total income received by or on behalf of the joint family

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme requires s.25A(1) precondition; proviso incidental to post-partition assessment/apportionment.

holdings.text: High Court order upheld but not for its reasons; appeals dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the High Court must, therefore, be confirmed and the appeals dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agree no personal recovery, but because no s.25A(1) at assessment, not retrospective reopening.
